Blues Servant Boy
King Blues
Georgia Slim | birth_date = {{Birth date|1902|03|16|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Charles City County, Virginia|Charles City County]], [[Virginia]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1972|05|11|1902|03|16|mf=y}} | death_place = [[New York City|New York]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Country blues]], [[Piedmont blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1924–1972 | label = Various | associated_acts = [[Louis Hayes (blues musician)|Louis Hayes]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Alec Seward''' (March 16, 1902 – May 11, 1972) was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues|Piedmont]] and [[Country blues|country]] [[blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p123900/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Alec Seward |author=Campbell, Al |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 7, 2010}} Some of his [[Gramophone record|records]] were released under [[pseudonyms]], such as '''Guitar Slim''', '''Blues Servant Boy''', '''King Blues''' and '''Georgia Slim'''. His best remembered [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were "Creepin' Blues" and "Some People Say".{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1970.html |title=The 1970s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} ==Biography== Seward, one of fourteen [[sibling]]s, was born in [[Charles City County, Virginia|Charles City County]], [[Virginia]]. Similar to [[Gabriel Brown]], [[Ralph Willis (blues musician)|Ralph Willis]] and [[Brownie McGhee]], Seward relocated from the [[Southern United States]] to [[New York City|New York]], in his case in 1924.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | isbn= 1-85868-255-X | page= 190}}{{cite book | first= Bruce | last= Bastin | year= 1995 | title= Red River Blues | edition= | publisher= University of Illinois Press | location= Illinois | isbn= 0-252-01213-5 | page= 333}} Seward befriended Brownie McGhee and [[Sonny Terry]], and retained his Piedmont blues styling despite changes in musical trends. He met [[Louis Hayes (blues musician)|Louis Hayes]] (who later became a minister in northern [[New Jersey]]) and the [[duet (music)|duo]] performed variously named as the Blues Servant Boys, Guitar Slim and Jelly Belly, or The Back Porch Boys. During the 1940s and 1950s Seward played and recorded with [[Lead Belly]], [[Woody Guthrie]], McGhee and Terry. Around 1947 Seward, Guthrie, and Terry, recorded several [[chain gang]] related songs including "Chain Gang Special", and some other older songs adapted to having chain gang themes. They were later released on the [[compilation album]], ''Best of the War Years''. Under his own real name, Seward issued ''Creepin' Blues'' (1965, [[Bluesville Records|Bluesville]]) with [[harmonica]] accompaniment by [[Larry Johnson (musician)|Larry Johnson]]. Later in the decade Seward worked in [[concert]] and at [[Country blues|folk-blues]] [[music festival|festivals]]. Seward died at the age of 70, in [[New York City|New York]] of [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]], in May 1972. He is not to be confused with [[Guitar Slim|Eddie "Guitar Slim" Jones]], [[Guitar Slim, Jr.]], James "Guitar Slim" Stephenson nor Norman "Guitar Slim" Green.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r581314|pure_url=yes}}|title=The Back Porch Boys|last=Henderson|first=Alex|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=8 February 2010}} ==Selected discography== *''Creepin' Blues'' (1965) – [[Bluesville Records|Bluesville]] *''Late One Saturday Evening'' (1996) – Blues Alliance *''The Back Porch Boys'' (2002) – [[Delmark Records|Delmark]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/alec-seward-mn0000519015/discography |title=Alec Seward | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/alec-seward-mn0000519015/discography/compilations |title=Alec Seward | Discography | Compilations |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} ==See also== *[[List of country blues musicians]] *[[East Coast blues]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=9443814}} {{Persondata | NAME =Seward, Alec | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues|Piedmont]] and [[Country blues|country]] [[blues]] singer, guitarist and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH =March 16, 1902 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Charles City County, Virginia]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH =May 11, 1972 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[New York City|New York]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seward, Alec}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Virginia]] [[Category:Country blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Virginia]] [[Category:Piedmont blues musicians]]
